newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Price fall halts early Brazil soybean sales - Safras.
newsitem.headline: Price fall halts early Brazil soybean sales - Safras.

text.p: The recent sharp fall in international soybean prices has practically stopped advance soybean sales from the Brazilian 1996/97 crop, independent consultants Safras e Mercado said in its weekly newsletter.
"Unless there are significant changes in the international market, the flow of sales should move slowly until the actual harvest, at least in the south and southeast," it said.

In its first survey carried out in the past two weeks, Safras estimates around 15 percent of the 1996/97 crop has already been committed, well above the average of the past five years, and due to the high prices seen through much of the year.
Sales of the new crop actually began in March even before the 1995/96 crop had been harvested, it added.
Advance sales by October 17 per state as estimated by Safras are as follows in 1,000 tonnes and in percentage terms.

In PARANA, the percentage already negotiated equals the record of 1994 and compares with an historical average of 12 percent. Around 800,000 of the 1.4 million tonnes already negotiated is destined for the export market.

In RIO GRANDE DO SUL, despite expectations of a better harvest, sales of the new crop are still very tentative given an historical average of five percent. Export sales are estimated at 80,000 tonnes of the total.
In MATO GROSSO, MATO GROSSO DO SUL and GOIAS, advance sales are very closely tied to the need for funds for plantings, Safras said.
-- Caroline Bulloch, Rio de Janeiro newsroom, 5521 5074151
